symptoms.quickFix: Reduce hydration slightly and ensure the loaf is fully baked.
symptoms.deepDive: A sunken middle often results from overproofing, excessive hydration, or underbaking. It indicates the loaf lacked structure to hold its shape during cooling.

symptoms.quickFix: Bake longer and let the loaf cool completely before slicing.
symptoms.deepDive: Gummy crumb often means the loaf was underbaked or cooled too quickly. High hydration and improper fermentation can also contribute.

symptoms.quickFix: Use a baking stone or lower oven rack and reduce temperature slightly.
symptoms.deepDive: Burnt bottoms typically result from baking too close to a heat source or using too much bottom heat. Pan insulation helps reduce scorching.

symptoms.quickFix: Let the dough rise longer until it passes the poke test.
symptoms.deepDive: Underproofing results in tight, dense crumbs. Gluten hasn't fully relaxed, leading to poor gas retention during baking.

symptoms.quickFix: Reduce final proof time or chill dough before baking.
symptoms.deepDive: Overproofed dough exhausts its gas-holding capacity, resulting in collapse or poor oven spring. Cold retardation can slow this down.

symptoms.quickFix: Score the loaf properly and shape with good tension.
symptoms.deepDive: Side blowouts occur when internal pressure escapes through weak seams. Scoring channels that energy into controlled expansion.

symptoms.quickFix: Extend baking time or increase oven temp slightly.
symptoms.deepDive: Pale crust can result from low sugar, underbaking, or insufficient heat. Steam also affects caramelization during the Maillard reaction.

symptoms.quickFix: Degas gently before final shaping.
symptoms.deepDive: Excessive air pockets result from poor shaping or uneven fermentation. Dough needs tension without aggressive deflation.

symptoms.quickFix: Use fresh yeast and warm environment (~75–80°F).
symptoms.deepDive: Cold temps, dead yeast, or salt inhibition can stall fermentation. Yeast activates best with warmth and hydration.

symptoms.quickFix: Add water gradually until dough is supple.
symptoms.deepDive: Dry dough leads to tight crumb and weak gluten development. Proper hydration is critical for extensibility and fermentation.

symptoms.quickFix: Increase hydration and knead until dough is smooth and elastic.
symptoms.deepDive: A dense, tight crumb indicates underhydration and/or insufficient gluten development during mixing and kneading. Achieving the right hydration level (around 65–70%) and using windowpane test ensures extensible, gas-retaining dough.

symptoms.quickFix: Score loaf deeply with a razor blade before baking.
symptoms.deepDive: Random splits on the loaf surface happen when steam can't escape through intentional scoring lines. Proper scoring guides expansion; weaker seams tear unpredictably. Use sharp blade and 30° angle cuts.

symptoms.quickFix: Reduce bulk fermentation time and proof at cooler temps.
symptoms.deepDive: Overfermented dough produces excess acidity, leading to an overly sour flavor. Shorten fermentation or use cooler proofing temperatures to moderate the tang while retaining complexity.

symptoms.quickFix: Increase salt by 0.2% of flour weight.
symptoms.deepDive: A lackluster flavor can stem from insufficient fermentation or salt levels. Salt enhances flavor and regulates yeast; small adjustments can bring out depth without overpowering.

symptoms.quickFix: Dust work surface lightly and rest dough briefly.
symptoms.deepDive: Sticky dough often indicates overhydration or underdeveloped gluten. Allowing the dough to rest (autolyse) before kneading can improve manageability without reducing hydration.

symptoms.quickFix: Preheat oven with baking stone and add steam for the first 10 minutes.
symptoms.deepDive: Poor oven spring can result from lack of oven heat retention or moisture. A hot baking surface and adequate steam help dough expand fully before crust sets.

symptoms.quickFix: Brush off steam vent early and bake a little longer uncovered.
symptoms.deepDive: A tough crust can be caused by excess moisture during baking or high humidity. Proper venting of steam and finishing the bake without steam encourages a crisp, thin crust.

symptoms.quickFix: Reduce baking time slightly and increase hydration by 2–3%.
symptoms.deepDive: Crumbly interior often happens when the crumb is overbaked or the dough is too dry. Increasing hydration and slightly underbaking by a minute or two preserves moisture.

symptoms.quickFix: Knead dough until it passes the windowpane test.
symptoms.deepDive: Weak gluten structure results in poor gas retention and collapse. Proper mixing and kneading align gluten strands. Use unbleached flour with high protein for stronger gluten.

symptoms.quickFix: Shape tight boules and rest seam-side down before baking.
symptoms.deepDive: Loaves that slump lose their shape from weak surface tension during proof. Tight shaping and seam-side rest builds strength. Correct bench rest time prevents overrelaxation.
